If you've just finished your first HYROX race—or you're training for one—you're probably wondering:

**"Is my HYROX time actually good?"**

Comparing your

**HYROX times** to other athletes can be confusing. A 1:30:00 finish might be world-class for a 55-year-old woman but average for a 25-year-old male athlete.

We analyzed

**over 700,000 HYROX race results** to give you real benchmarks for **HYROX times**—not aspirational guesses, but actual data from real athletes across all age groups.

**New to HYROX?** Start with our complete beginner's guide to learn the basics, or use our free pacing calculator to plan your race strategy.

## Average HYROX Times by Performance Level

Here's what most people want to know upfront—

**real HYROX times** from 700,000+ finishers:

|Performance Level|Men's Time|Women's Time|Percentile|
|--|--|--|--|
|Beginner|1:40:00 - 1:54:00|1:54:00 - 2:10:00|50-75th|
|Intermediate|1:25:00 - 1:40:00|1:38:00 - 1:54:00|25-50th|
|Advanced|1:15:00 - 1:25:00|1:26:00 - 1:38:00|10-25th|
|Elite|Under 1:15:00|Under 1:26:00|Top 10%|
### Men (Open/Individual)

**Beginner:**1:40:00 - 1:54:00 **Intermediate:**1:25:00 - 1:40:00 **Advanced:**1:15:00 - 1:25:00 **Elite:**Under 1:15:00

### Women (Open/Individual)

**Beginner:**1:54:00 - 2:12:00 **Intermediate:**1:37:00 - 1:54:00 **Advanced:**1:24:00 - 1:37:00 **Elite:**Under 1:24:00

Age matters significantly! A 1:24:00 finish for a 55-year-old man is elite (top 10%), while it's advanced for a 25-year-old. Keep reading for detailed breakdowns by age group.✅

**Want to improve your HYROX time?** Our 12-Week HYROX Training Program provides structured workouts and proven strategies built from analyzing 700,000+ race results. **Just $29.99** — get race-ready faster with data-driven programming.

## What Defines a "Good" HYROX Time?

We use percentile rankings based on actual race data:

**Beginner (40th-60th percentile):**You finished! That's an achievement. You're faster than 40% of participants. **Intermediate (60th-70th percentile):**Solid performance. You've trained consistently and know the stations. Top 40% of all finishers. **Advanced (70th-90th percentile):**Competitive athlete. You're targeting podium spots at local races. Top 30% of all finishers. **Elite (90th+ percentile):**Top 10%. You're in contention for age group wins and regional podiums.

**Ready to move up a category?** If you want to improve your HYROX time and reach the next performance level, check out our comprehensive training program that has helped athletes cut 10-20 minutes off their finish times. **Limited time offer: $29.99** for the complete 12-week program.

## Detailed Benchmarks by Age & Gender

### Men's Open Division

|Age Group|Beginner|Intermediate|Advanced|Elite|
|--|--|--|--|--|
|18-24|1:47:00|1:34:00|1:23:00|1:12:00|
|25-29|1:47:00|1:34:00|1:21:00|1:13:00|
|30-34|1:55:00|1:42:00|1:25:00|1:15:00|
|35-39|1:56:00|1:38:00|1:24:00|1:14:00|
|40-44|1:58:00|1:44:00|1:31:00|1:22:00|
|45-49|1:54:00|1:44:00|1:29:00|1:19:00|
|50-54|1:58:00|1:47:00|1:33:00|1:21:00|
|55-59|2:05:00|1:52:00|1:36:00|1:24:00|
|60+|2:30:00|1:53:00|1:41:00|1:28:00|
### Women's Open Division

|Age Group|Beginner|Intermediate|Advanced|Elite|
|--|--|--|--|--|
|18-24|1:57:00|1:45:00|1:33:00|1:25:00|
|25-29|2:06:00|1:54:00|1:34:00|1:20:00|
|30-34|2:14:00|1:56:00|1:35:00|1:23:00|
|35-39|2:15:00|1:57:00|1:38:00|1:28:00|
|40-44|2:15:00|1:54:00|1:39:00|1:26:00|
|45-49|2:16:00|1:59:00|1:40:00|1:29:00|
|50-54|2:24:00|1:55:00|1:43:00|1:26:00|
|55-59|1:55:00|1:46:00|1:38:00|1:26:00|
|60+|2:21:00|1:58:00|1:50:00|1:41:00|
## How HYROX Times Compare to Other Sports

Athletes often ask: "I run a 20-minute 5K—what HYROX time should I expect?"

#### Key Takeaway

HYROX is fundamentally different from pure running or CrossFit. Your 5K PR won't directly predict your HYROX time. The strength stations level the playing field between runners and strength athletes.

### Common Athlete Profiles

**The Runner**

- 5K: 18-20 min

- Strength training: Minimal

- Expected HYROX: 1:30-1:40 (men), 1:50-2:00 (women)

**Bottleneck:**Sled push (152kg/102kg), sled pull, wall balls

**The CrossFitter**

- 5K: 22-24 min

- CrossFit: 3+ years

- Expected HYROX: 1:25-1:35 (men), 1:40-1:50 (women)

**Bottleneck:**Running endurance, pacing the 8km

**The Balanced Athlete**

- 5K: 20-22 min

- Strength training: 2-3x/week

- Expected HYROX: 1:20-1:30 (men), 1:35-1:45 (women)

**Advantage:**No major weaknesses

Pure runners often overestimate their HYROX performance by 10-15 minutes, while CrossFitters underestimate theirs by 5-10 minutes. Train both equally for best results.

## What Makes an Elite HYROX Time?

Breaking into elite territory (

**sub-1:15 men**, **sub-1:24 women**) requires four key elements:

### Sub-5:00/km Running Pace

Elite athletes average

**4:30-4:50/km** across all 8km of running, even when fatigued from stations.

### Station Efficiency

|Station|Elite Time (Men)|Elite Time (Women)|
|--|--|--|
|SkiErg (1000m)|3:50-4:20|4:30-5:00|
|Sled Push (152kg/102kg)|2:50-3:26|2:50-3:25|
|Sled Pull (103kg/78kg)|3:50-4:37|4:15-4:59|
|Burpee Broad Jumps|4:00-4:37|5:15-5:57|
|Row (1000m)|4:00-4:33|4:45-5:11|
|Farmers Carry (48kg/32kg)|1:45-1:59|2:00-2:15|
|Lunges (20kg/10kg)|3:50-4:24|4:00-4:30|
|Wall Balls (100 reps)|5:30-6:04|5:20-5:53|
One bad station can cost you 5-10 minutes. Elite athletes have NO stations slower than 80th percentile—they're well-rounded, not specialists.

### Minimal RoxZone Time

Elite athletes average 4-5 minutes total RoxZone time. Intermediate athletes average 7-8.5 minutes, while beginners may take 9-12 minutes or more.

**RoxZone includes:**

- Running from finish line to station

- Running from station to next start line

- Brief mental prep and equipment setup

### Mental Toughness

The ability to maintain pace when everything hurts. Elite athletes don't slow down—they manage discomfort better.

## How to Improve Your HYROX Time

Based on your current level:

### Beginners (1:40-2:10)

**Focus:** Finish strong, build base fitness

**Training priorities:**

- Run 3-4x per week at conversational pace

- Practice all 8 stations 1x per week

- Focus on technique before speed

Don't worry about speed yet. Learn proper form on all stations—especially sled push/pull technique with the heavy weights (152kg/103kg for men, 102kg/78kg for women).✅

**🎯 Ready to train smarter?** Our 12-Week HYROX Training Program takes you from beginner to race-ready with structured workouts, station technique guides, and proven pacing strategies. Just **$29.99** — less than a single PT session. Start training smart today.

### Intermediate (1:25-1:40 / 1:37-1:54)

**Focus:** Identify weak stations, improve pacing

**Training priorities:**

- Track your split times—find your slowest 2 stations using our race analyzer tool

- Add 1-2 specific station workouts per week

- Practice negative splitting (running faster as race progresses)

- Use our pacing calculator to set realistic split targets

**Example weakness work:**

- Slow at sled push? Add 2x/week heavy sled work

- Slow at wall balls? Practice 100-rep sets 2x/week

### Advanced (1:15-1:25 / 1:24-1:37)

**Focus:** Fine-tune pacing, maximize efficiency

**Training priorities:**

- Interval training 2x per week (tempo runs, VO2 max)

- Station-specific drills 2-3x per week at race weight

- Practice race-pace RoxZone transitions (sprint between stations)

- Mental toughness training (running under fatigue)

- Analyze your performance data with our race analyzer tool

**Want to break through to the next level?** Our structured 12-week program includes progressive periodization, race simulation protocols, and advanced pacing strategies designed to take intermediate athletes to sub-1:20 performance.

### Elite (under 1:15 / 1:24)

**Focus:** Marginal gains, competition strategy

**Training priorities:**

- Periodized training blocks (build, peak, taper)

- Race simulation workouts every 2-3 weeks

- Video analysis of technique on all stations

- Strategic pacing per course (elevation, heat, competition)

## Realistic Time Improvement Expectations💡

Most athletes improve 15-25% from their first to second race simply by understanding pacing, knowing the stations, and better race-day nutrition.

**First year:** 15-25% improvement

**Year 2-3:** 5-10% annual improvement with consistent training

**Plateau:** Most athletes plateau after 3-5 years unless they significantly change training

### Example Progression (Male, 30-34):

**First race:**1:55:00 (beginner) **6 months later:**1:40:00 (intermediate) → 13% improvement **1 year later:**1:25:00 (advanced) → 15% improvement **2 years later:**1:15:00 (elite) → 12% improvement **3+ years:**1:10-1:14 (peak elite performance)

## Station Benchmarks: Where Are You Losing Time?

Here's what "good" looks like for each station (Men / Women, Intermediate level):

|Station|Intermediate (M/W)|Advanced (M/W)|
|--|--|--|
|SkiErg|4:27 / 5:11|4:20 / 5:00|
|Sled Push|3:41 / 3:42|3:26 / 3:25|
|Sled Pull|5:06 / 5:34|4:37 / 4:59|
|Burpee Broad Jumps|5:19 / 6:50|4:37 / 5:57|
|Row|4:44 / 5:24|4:33 / 5:11|
|Farmers Carry|2:10 / 2:25|1:59 / 2:15|
|Lunges|4:56 / 5:01|4:24 / 4:30|
|Wall Balls|7:01 / 6:51|6:04 / 5:53|
If any of your stations are slower than the "Intermediate" column, that's your biggest opportunity for improvement. Focus 50% of your training on your weakest 2 stations.

## Your Next Steps

Now that you know where you stand:

**Log your last race splits**— Find your weak stations **Set a realistic goal**— Aim for 1 category improvement (Beginner → Intermediate) **Train specifically**— Dedicate 2x per week to your weakest station **Track progress**— Retest stations every 4-6 weeks

#### Key Takeaway

A "good" HYROX time is relative to your age, gender, and training background. Focus on improving YOUR time, not comparing yourself to elites. Every PR is worth celebrating.

## FAQs

**Q: What's the average HYROX finish time?**

A: Men average around 1:40:00, women average around 1:54:00 across all age groups and divisions. The median (50th percentile) is slightly faster at 1:33-1:38 for men and 1:47-1:52 for women.

**Q: Is sub 1:30 good for a first race?**

A: Absolutely! Sub 1:30 for men puts you in the advanced category (top 30%). For women, sub 1:45 is also advanced level.

**Q: How long does it take to go from beginner to elite?**

A: Most athletes need 3-5 years of consistent, structured training. Expect 10-20% annual improvement in your first 2 years.

**Q: Do pros use different weights?**

A: No. Pro and Open athletes use the same weights (152kg sled push for men, 102kg for women). Only age group 60+ uses modified weights.

**Q: Why are the sleds so heavy?**

A: HYROX uses 152kg (men) and 102kg (women) for sled push to test strength-endurance. The heavy sleds separate pure runners from hybrid athletes.

## Frequently Asked Questions About HYROX Times

### What is a good HYROX time for beginners?

For beginners, a good HYROX time is 1:40-1:54 for men and 1:54-2:10 for women. If you finish your first race in this range, you're performing better than about 50% of HYROX athletes. Focus on completing the race and building a baseline—you can improve your times with targeted training.

### What is the average HYROX time?

The average HYROX time for men is approximately 1:35, while women average around 1:50. However, this varies significantly by age group, with younger athletes (25-35) typically finishing 5-10 minutes faster than those in the 45-55 age bracket.

### What HYROX time is considered elite?

Elite HYROX times are under 1:15 for men and under 1:26 for women. These times put you in the top 10% of all HYROX finishers globally and typically require years of focused training in both running and functional fitness.

### How do HYROX times vary by age?

HYROX times typically slow by 2-3 minutes per decade after age 35. A 1:30 time for a 25-year-old male would be equivalent to approximately 1:37 for a 45-year-old athlete with similar training. Our age group analysis shows detailed breakdowns by age bracket.

## Conclusion

Your best time is one you're proud of. Whether you're chasing a PR, trying to beat a friend, or just finishing your first race—every HYROX time represents hours of hard work.

Use these benchmarks to set realistic goals and train smarter, not to judge your worth as an athlete.

**Related Articles:**

- Age Group Performance Analysis — Detailed age breakdown

- Average Split Times by Age Group — Realistic benchmarks

- First HYROX Race Guide — Complete beginner guide

- How to Beat 1:30 — Complete training requirements

# Roxzone

The "Roxzone" in HYROX events refers to the area between the running track and the functional stations, typically located in a large indoor arena. This transitional zone, where athletes move from running around the perimeter to the central functional stations, can add approximately 1km to the total distance covered.

It's a significant aspect often overlooked in gym simulations. Within the Roxzone, competitors have access to water and energy drink, but receiving external supplies like drinks or food from spectators is not permitted, although carrying personal items is allowed.

## Inside HYROX’s New Turf Era and What It Means for Your Training

I remember the first time I walked onto a HYROX sled lane. That thin strip of carpet, duct taped down at the edges, sticky in some parts, slick in others, instantly gave me the sense that no two races would ever feel the same. And honestly, they didn’t. Anyone who has done more than one HYROX knows that how your sled feels on race day is almost a coin toss. Sometimes it glides. Sometimes it drags like you’re pushing a car stuck in mud.

## Well, that era might finally be over.

HYROX has just introduced a brand new competition surface for their sled stations. It is called the HYROX x Centr Perform Turf and it made its debut at the 2025 World Championships in Chicago. From now on, this is the turf you will be pushing and pulling on, whether you are racing in London, New York, or anywhere else across their global circuit.

This might sound like a minor tweak. It is not. This is one of the biggest practical changes the sport has made since it began.

…

To solve this, HYROX has partnered with Centr - yes, the same Centr that was co-founded by Chris Hemsworth and later acquired by HighPost Capital - to develop a modular turf designed specifically for sled work. According to HYROX, they tested over 200,000 sled movements across different materials to get the formula right. They wanted something that felt grippy but not grabby, smooth but still demanding.
The result is a custom 16 millimeter turf with a pile height that reduces carpet bunching, maintains durability, and gives a more consistent push across all lanes.

That all sounds great in theory. But what about in practice?

## Chicago is the Big Reveal

Next week’s World Championships in Chicago will be the first time the new HYROX x Centr Perform Turf is used in an official race. Until now, no regular HYROX event has featured this surface. All previous qualifiers, including New York and London, were still run on the traditional carpet system.
So while HYROX has tested the turf behind closed doors - including some trials at private venues - Chicago will be the first time thousands of athletes run, push, and pull on it under full race conditions.

That means nobody truly knows how it will hold up over a full day of elite and open heats. There is a lot riding on it. HYROX says the turf has been tested for over two hundred thousand sled movements, but competition is a different beast.

…

## What does this mean for training?

If you are a gym owner, a HYROX coach, or just someone chasing a PB on race day, this new turf matters. HYROX has said that their Performance Centres - the official gyms they partner with - will eventually install the same turf to give members a more authentic race prep. That is huge. It means no more guessing what your sled will feel like on race day. It means fewer nasty surprises at your next event.

results.snippet:
HYROX has announced a significant upgrade to its race and training experiences with the launch of a custom-engineered HYROX Perform Turf in collaboration with global equipment partner Centr.

The end product of rigorous wear testing and materials experimentation, this new sled turf will ensure optimal sled push and pull conditions, producing an optimal, super consistent and durable surface, which results in the same base resistance as the previous carpets. Athletes will have a first chance to experience the new turf at the World Championships in Chicago 2025.
Mintra Tilly, Director of Sports at HYROX commented:

*“We are now creating individual athletic experiences for hundreds of thousands of athletes in competitions and millions in training. We want to ensure that each of those experiences reflects our obsession with performance and creating a surface for the sleds which has been engineered from the ground up to standardise our athletes’ experience has been a key strategic focus for us”*
The HYROX X Centr Perform Turf will also be available for HYROX Training Clubs and Performance Centers to offer the exact race environment their members will have on race day.

Key aspects of the roll-out include:

**OFFICIAL RACE TURF**

Designed and tested by athletes, for athletes, the Centr x HYROX Perform Turf is used in HYROX races worldwide, specially engineered for athletic movements, sled pulls, and sled pushes.
**SUPERIOR TRACTION, SAFER MOVEMENTS**

Turf density and pile height support optimal traction to ensure safety for hybrid training and fast-paced competition movements. The non-abrasive pile is 16mm in height, offering more movement control and consistency in training.

**BUILT TO LAST**

The development process included over 200,000 simulated wear tests, with ongoing endurance testing to ensure maximum durability for training and competitions.
**CONFIGURABLE DESIGN**

Modular competition lane system allows gyms to create customized training areas with adjustable lane and end zone configurations.

Inconsistencies with how the sleds can feel from event to event, but also in different lanes, in HYROX, has long been a controversial aspect of the sport. Hopefully the new turf will ensure greater consistency throughout the sport!

HWPO HYROX Boston takes place from Friday, September 26th through Sunday, September 28th at the Boston Convention Center. Over 5,000 athletes are expected to race across Open, Pro, Doubles, Adaptive, and Relay divisions.

HYROX has released the official course map for HYROX Boston, which includes station placement, the Roxzone, and number of run laps to be completed for each 1,000m run. You’ll also find information about registration, check-in, bag check, restrooms, and more.

## How Many Laps to Run

For HYROX Boston, the number of laps you have to run vary depending on which run you are on.

Advertisement:

**For the first lap,** you’ll do about 2 and a half laps, and enter the Roxzone the **THIRD** time you see the IN arch.

**For laps 2-8,** you’ll do exactly 2 laps, and enter the Roxzone the **SECOND** time you see the IN arch.

…

**The ski (1) & row (5)**will be immediately on your **LEFT**as you enter the Roxzone **The farmer’s carry (6) and sandbag lunges (7)**will be immediately on your **RIGHT**as you enter the Roxzone **For the sled push (2) and
sled pull (3),**you’ll run straight ahead, and then slightly off to your right **For the burpee broad jumps (4),**you’ll run **STRAIGHT AHEAD**after entering the Roxzone **The wall balls (8)**are over by the BBJs, but we couldn’t tell you exactly how you’ll get to them. It’s not clear from the map.

### Grandstand

There will be a grandstand over by the wall balls, so all your friends can watch you suffer through 100 reps… and cheer you on, of course 😀.

- Read more in our full HYROX spectator guide →

results.snippet:
Here’s an example HYROX race layout from the North American Championships in Washington, DC, USA in March 2025.

**The yellow striped rectangle on the far right**is where spectators cross into the viewing area **The black with yellow striped area**is open to spectators to watch the action

The HYROX race format will always contain the following:

- The HYROX start tunnel

- A running track around the outside of the venue

- Workout stations situated inside of the running track

- Some additional space inside the running track, before you reach each workout station (aka: the Roxzone)

- Finish line

…

Please reference your specific HYROX race map to see how many laps you need to complete.

The running track contains two lanes—a fast lane and a regular lane. Try to stay in the regular lane, unless you are passing someone. As each new wave of athletes is released, they will likely take off in the fast lane, so be aware of your surroundings.

Once you’ve completed your 1km run around the track…

### In & Out Arches

The in & out arches are an important component to understanding the HYROX race format. These are the openings in the running track where you will enter and exit the running track to go in and out of the Roxzone, where all the workout stations are found.

They are usually located on the same side of the running track, but sometimes the in arch will be closer to the start line, and sometimes the out arch is closer. It just depends on your venue.
You always enter the Roxzone through the IN arch and exit the Roxzone back onto the running track via the OUT arch. Penalties are assessed for going in or out the wrong arch.

### Roxzone

As soon as you exit the running track to head to a workout station, you enter what is called the Roxzone. You may walk, jog, or run through the Roxzone to get to the station you need to complete.

The Roxzone at each race is different, but your split times will include how much time you spent in the Roxzone throughout the race.
Most hydration stations are found within the Roxzone.

It’s important to note that while you might think a HYROX race consists of 8km of running (8 x 1km laps), HYROX has stated that the running laps combined with the distance in the Roxzone always equals 8.7km total.

You will run in the Roxzone to find the arch with the name/number of your next station.

### Workout Stations

At every HYROX, the 8 workout stations are always contained within the inside of the running track. However, they are not always in the same order, or even the order that they are to be completed. It’s your responsibility to remember which station you are on, and find the appropriate arch for that station.

You’ll enter through the station arch to complete your station work.

Upon finishing your station work, you’ll travel through the Roxzone, but this time you’ll look for the OUT arch to get back onto the running track.

### Finish Line

You’ll complete this process 8 times, and finish with the final station, wall balls. There is no run after the wall balls—you run up the ramp to the finish line, where you can look for your name & finishing time on the giant screen.

And that is the HYROX layout, in a nutshell.

…

#### Spectator Grandstand

You might also see this referred to as the “HYROX Thunderdome,” but this is essentially a large seating area for spectators to watch the event. It is almost always situated in and around station 8, the wall balls.

Any athlete or spectator may visit this area as often as they’d like throughout the day to watch the action unfold.

HYROX® Race format is 8 x 1 km runs + 8 stations, always in the same order. However, being familiar with the movements, what you need to know, transition tips and at gym alternatives is key. The winners are less about maximal fitness and more about pacing discipline, clean mechanics, and Roxzone skill.

…

ROXZONE is the clearly marked transition corridor that guides athletes into and out of each workout station. It standardizes flow, keeps athletes in the correct lanes, and gives judges a safe, visible area to brief you and confirm standards. You must enter the appropriate station through the ROXZONE boundaries; skipping or entering the wrong way can result in penalties. Length and layout vary by venue (some are long and curved, others short and direct), so pacing and awareness here matter—your total race time includes all movement through the ROXZONE.
**Race‑day checklist for the ROXZONE**

• Walk the route during warm‑up. Note where each station's entry/exit is and the judge position.

• Eyes up 20 m out. Read signage early so you don't overshoot the station entrance.

• Control your breathing. Two calm exhales as you enter; posture tall to reset the trunk.
• Set‑and‑go script. Example for sled: hands set → feet set → brace → start. No dithering.

• Mind the lane. Don't block other athletes or drop equipment outside the station boundary.

• Exit clean. Park handles/rope/ball exactly as directed; then accelerate smoothly back to the run.
**The Roxzone **

**Enter → take 3–5 tall breaths.**

- Organize the station before touching equipment (avoid mid-set fixes).

- One clear cadence/rep plan; no in-set debating.

- Exit with posture — no folded running.

**Official Station Standards**

Loads shown for sleds are including sled; friction varies by venue. Wall ball targets: Women/Women Pro 2.70 m, Men/Men Pro 3.00 m.

…

**How to move:**

- Angle low, elbows in, long spine, short quick steps.

- Push to the end cone, rest only at the end; exhale with steps.

- If sled is light, slow tempo to increase time under tension.

**Roxzone & SMS:**

- Finish length → stand tall 5–7 s → shake legs → jog out under control.

…

• Builder: 3 × 700 m @ RPE 7, 75 s rest, rating cap 24–26 spm.

• Race‑ready: 2 × (500 m row @ RPE 8 → 300 m run slightly faster than race pace), 90 s rest.

**Station 6 — Farmer's Carry (200 m)**
What it really tests: Late-race posture, grip, and patience.

Cues: ribs down, tall posture, short steps, firm clamp grip, tidy turns. Leaks: lateral sway, over‑stride, dropping handles at turns.

**Common mistakes:**

- Swingy bells; rounded trunk; frequent random drops.

- Over-striding to hurry the carry.

…

• Race‑ready: 2 rounds: 50 m lunges → 300 m run race pace → 50 m lunges; even splits.

**Station 8 — Wall Balls**

Cues: heels down, tall chest, full depth, smooth breathing, steady target lock. Leaks: shallow depth, chasing the ball, massive first set then blow‑up.

…

**Roxzone & SMS:**

- Enter → set feet → deliver the first set you planned; micro-breaks ≤ 5 s to keep cadence.

**Pacing cues:**

- Last block is about cadence and accuracy, not hero sprints.

**Practice options:**

- EMOM 10: 10 wall balls (race target) → 400 m easy.

- 30 wall balls → 200 m run → 1:00 rest × 3.

Creating the perfect flooring for a high-impact Hyrox training gym requires a unique mix of durability, comfort, and specialised design to support a wide range of activities, from heavy lifting and high-intensity interval training to speed lanes for agility drills.

Each type of flooring in the gym serves a unique function, and understanding these differences can help maximise both performance and safety.
Below, we’ll dive deeper into Hyrox, what's involved and how you can create the perfect Hyrox training setup. Whether you're outfitting an existing gym space or looking to support Hyrox training at-home, we'll look at the best hyrox training flooring options that not only optimise safety but elevate your performance.

## Table of Contents

How Often Are Hyrox Events Held?

Types of Hyrox Classes and Workouts

What Equipment is Used in Hyrox Workout Stations?

What Type of Flooring do I need for Hyrox training?

## What is Hyrox?

Hyrox is a rapidly growing fitness competition that combines endurance, functional strength, and high-intensity interval training in a unique and challenging format. Originally founded in Germany, Hyrox has gained traction world-wide and is now a popular event series in the UK, attracting everyone from fitness enthusiasts to elite athletes.

…

**Farmers Carry**– Walking with weights to build grip and core strength.



**Sandbag Lunges**– Weighted lunges using a sandbag.



**Wall Balls**– Throwing a weighted ball to a target, testing endurance and coordination.

The event format is the same for each Hyrox race, and competitors can participate individually or in pairs. With multiple categories available, including Men’s, Women’s, Mixed Doubles, and various age divisions, Hyrox events are open to all fitness levels.

…

## Types of Hyrox Classes and Workouts

Hyrox gyms offer a variety of classes and hyrox equipment, focused on the event's core components, including:



**HYROX Endurance**– Focuses on aerobic conditioning and running stamina.



**HYROX Strength**– Emphasizes building the power and strength needed for exercises like the sled push and sandbag lunges.
**HYROX Technique**– Helps athletes perfect the specific skills and movements required for each workout station.



**HYROX Race Simulation**– A full-length workout that mimics the complete event, allowing participants to prepare for the demands of race day.

Classes can vary in intensity and duration, making them suitable for everyone from beginners to advanced athletes.

…

**Sleds**for pushing and pulling, which build lower body and core strength.



**Sandbags**for lunges and carries, which help improve functional strength.



**Farmers Carry weights**(usually kettlebells or dumbbells) for grip strength.



**Wall Balls**for explosive movements and coordination.



**Weighted Vests**(used in advanced training) to add resistance and increase workout difficulty.

## What Type of Flooring do I need for Hyrox training?

With such a wide combination of activities involved in Hyrox training, the gym flooring should be versatile, extra hardwearing and be strong enough to withstand heavy weights and equipment. Let's look at the top flooring options for the various functional workout stations.

**Heavy Duty Rubber Tiles for Weightlifting Zones**
When it comes to the heavy lifting areas of a gym, durability and impact-resistance are paramount. Heavy duty rubber tiles or olympic weightlifting flooring, typically available in thicker formats (20mm to 40mm) are engineered specifically to handle the weight and force of heavy weights, kettlebells, and other lifting equipment.
**Key Benefits**:



**Exceptional Durability**: These tiles are built to withstand repeated impact from heavy weights, which makes them ideal for deadlift and powerlifting areas. Likewise, rubber tiles will also protect your equipment from premature wear and tear.



**Shock Absorption**: The added thickness provides excellent shock absorption, protecting both the subfloor and equipment from damage while also reducing noise and vibration.
**Anti-Slip Surface**: Rubber tiles generally have a textured, anti-slip surface, which is crucial in a high-intensity environment where safety is paramount.

**Considerations**:



**Installation**: Thicker rubber tiles are typically available in interlocking styles, which makes installation more straightforward and minimises movement over time.
**Maintenance**: Rubber tiles are generally easy to clean, but regular maintenance will ensure they stay in peak condition. They’re also water-resistant, which is essential in any area that will see moisture and humidity from perspiration.

**Customer Feedback:**

"Our gym flooring has made a huge difference to training at home. It feels like a professional gym, is much kinder on your legs and it cancels out noise so well. Very happy with the look and quality of these tiles."
**Ultra-Smooth Self-Locking Rubber Mats for Comfort and Versatility**

For areas requiring more versatile flooring, ultra-smooth interlocking gym mats are an ideal choice. Interlocking tiles usually come in a 20mm thickness which allows for weight-based activities as well as functional training and conditioning workouts.

What makes these tiles a good choice for Hyrox is their versatility, extra stability and comfort. The hidden connection inserts keep the tiles held tightly together so that the surface remains in position even throughout the most intense training sessions.
**Key Benefits**:



**Quick and Simple Installation**: Self-locking mats are designed for easy installation, which saves time and eliminates the need for adhesives. Their edges interlock snugly, keeping them securely in place during workouts.



**Enhanced Comfort**: With a slightly softer surface than heavy-duty tiles, these mats add comfort underfoot, especially for exercises that involve getting down on the floor.
**Shock Absorption**: While not as thick as heavy-duty rubber tiles, these mats still offer a good level of shock absorption, helping protect users from impact-related injuries.

**Considerations**:



**Flexibility**: If the gym layout changes frequently, these mats are ideal as they’re easy to uninstall and move around.
**Cleaning**: Self-locking mats are generally low-maintenance, but their smooth surface makes them easy to wipe down, which is perfect for high-traffic areas.

**Functional Training Turf for Speed Lanes and Agility Tracks**

Functional training turf, often used in the form of speed lanes, agility tracks or sled tracks are becoming a popular addition in high-impact gyms. Designed specifically for sprinting, sled work, and agility drills, turf provides a versatile surface that complements more intense and dynamic training activities.
**Key Benefits**:



**Specialised for Functional Training**: This turf is made to endure high-speed, high-impact movements, making it ideal for speed and agility work that is central to Hyrox training.



**Durable and Resilient**: Functional training turf is built to last, even under heavy use. The fibres are designed to withstand dragging, pushing, and pulling motions without wearing down.
**Traction and Stability**: Turf offers excellent traction for users, which helps in preventing slips during quick changes in direction. It also provides a stable surface for sled pushes and other resistance work.

**Considerations**:



**Customisation**: Speed lanes and agility tracks can be customised with markings, which adds to the aesthetic and functional appeal of the gym.
**Maintenance**: Regular brushing and cleaning are essential to keep the turf looking fresh and to prevent wear from accumulated dirt and sweat.

**Rubber Rolls for Seamless Cardio Areas**

For the cardio zones where machines like treadmills, bikes, and rowers are placed, rubber matting roll provides a seamless and protective surface that is ideal for both high and low-impact activities. Rubber roll flooring is a top choice for its resilience and versatility, as it can cover large areas with minimal seams, enhancing both the look and functionality of the gym floor.
**Key Benefits**:



**Continuous and Seamless Surface**: Rubber rolls create a smooth, continuous surface without the need for as many seams, reducing the chances of tripping or separation over time.



**Noise Reduction**: The rubber absorbs sound, helping to muffle the noise from cardio machines, which contributes to a more pleasant gym environment.
**Protects the Subfloor**: Rubber roll flooring acts as a protective barrier between heavy cardio machines and the subfloor, preventing indentations and scratches from equipment.

**Considerations**:



**Installation**: Rubber rolls may require professional installation for best results, as they need to be cut to fit the space precisely.
**Easy Maintenance**: The seamless nature of rubber rolls makes it easy to clean and maintain, ideal for spaces with heavy foot traffic.

**Selecting the Right Flooring Mix for a High-Impact Hyrox Gym**

Each type of flooring in a Hyrox gym plays a unique role in supporting different activities. Here’s a quick summary to help make the right flooring choices:
**Heavy Duty Rubber Tiles**: Essential for weightlifting areas that experience heavy impacts.



**Ultra-Smooth Self-Locking Rubber Mats**: Ideal for versatile training zones and quick installation.



**Functional Training Turf**: Perfect for agility and speed drills, adding a dynamic element to the gym.



**Rubber Rolls**: Provides a seamless, protective surface for cardio zones, ensuring stability and durability.

## Conclusion

By carefully choosing and combining these training floor types you can create the perfect environment for hyrox and meets the demands of these intense workouts, while ensuring longevity, safety, and comfort for gym-goers.

Whether you’re designing a new gym or upgrading an existing space for hyrox classes, the right flooring mix can elevate the overall training experience and support a full range of activities within a single, cohesive space.

Discover Bestselling gym floor solutions for your Hyrox facility by checking out our fitness flooring collection.
results.title: Top Flooring Options for a Hyrox Gym

results.snippet:
## Workout stations in Hyrox

Hyrox races are made up of 8 x 1km runs and 8 x functional workouts. Starting in the Red Bull tunnel you head out into your first run then into the Roxzone to complete your workout. This is repeated up until the final workout in the Thunder Dome for your 100 wall balls, then takes racers across the finish line.

…

## Navigating the racecourse

For some, this may seem the most daunting part of the day, but I assure you the race is laid out very clearly and you won't get lost.

Race layouts are sent out with packs and are available online. These will identify the Warm Up area, Start Zone, the IN and OUT from the run to the roxzone into the functional workouts, how the functional workouts are placed (these may not be in numerical order), the location of the hydration stations, the finish line and recovery area.
I highly recommend viewing this and then arriving on race day early to walk the set-up so you are ready to race.

What makes it easier is that you should easily be able to spot large inflatable arches that will mark:

- the IN route for leaving the run course.

- the OUT arch for leaving the roxzone for your next run.

- the station numbers and what they are, so you won't miss a station or confuse the order.

And if you're in doubt, there are judges, race directors and volunteers everywhere in the roxzone to help you get to the right place.
results.title: Structure of a Hyrox Race: What to Expect - PureGym

As Hyrox continues to grow across Singapore, more gyms are upgrading their functional areas with

**Hyrox astro turf** or **custom turf lanes** built specifically for sled push, sled pull, sprint drills and high-intensity conditioning. Unlike standard green turf used for décor or light fitness activities, Hyrox-grade turf is engineered for **speed, traction, and repeated sled resistance**, making it essential for performance-driven gyms and functional studios.
At GymFlooring.sg, we specialise in providing

**custom Hyrox turf lanes** tailored to gym layouts, branding and training requirements — from standard 10–15m lanes to fully customised turf with race markings, arrows, zone labels and gym logos. **Why Hyrox Gyms in Singapore Use Astro Turf Lanes**
Hyrox training involves repeated functional movements at high intensity, which makes the flooring surface extremely important. Hyrox turf offers:

**1. Perfect Glide for Sled Push & Sled Pull Work**

Hyrox astro turf provides the

**ideal friction level** for sled work — smooth enough for consistent pushing, yet resistant enough to build powerful leg drive. **2. Traction for Sprinting & Conditioning**

Sled push

Running starts

Power strides

Functional conditioning drills

Walking lunges

Hyrox stations that require repeated floor contact

**4. High Visibility & Zone Control**

Hyrox gyms frequently use turf to create clear movement zones for:

Sled lanes

Relay runs

Conditioning tracks

Functional training circuits

contents.snippet:
**HYROX has officially dropped its updated rulebook for the 2025/26 season – **and while there are no drastic changes to the sport’s core format, there are a few key updates every athlete, judge, and fan should be aware of.

From refined movement standards and stricter judging to the formalization of competition categories like Elite Doubles, the new rulebook aims to bring more consistency and professionalism to the race floor.

**Here’s a quick breakdown of what’s new, what’s clarified, and what it means for your next race.**

**Movement standards:** **Ski / Row**– Erg dampers will now be set to 6 for all divisions but can be changed **Sled Pull –**Athletes must not step on the solid white line at the front of the athletes’ box **Burpee Broad Jumps**– Rule clarification: Athletes are permitted to use their knees to step up to standing

**Penalties & Disqualification: ** **Wave Start Time**– Starting in any wave other than your official assigned wave start time will result in disqualification **Doubles Teams**– If a doubles team gets more than 3 infringements for being too far apart this will result in disqualification **Sleds, Burpee Broad Jumps & Sandbag Lunges**– There will be no more distance-based penalties, instead there will be one warning followed by a time-based penalty of 15 seconds per infringement after the warning **Farmer’s Carry**– Depending on the venue, Farmers Carry may involve multiple laps. Each missing lap will result in a 3-minute penalty **Farmer’s Carry & Sandbag Lunges**– Athletes must redo this station if the wrong weight is used and failure to redo it with the correct weight will result in disqualification **Spitting / Clearing nose**– If athletes spit or clear their nose on the floor or carpet, this will result in a 2-minute penalty per infringement

**Additional:** **Transgender Rankings**– In line with previous Olympic guidelines, official rankings will be based on a participant’s biological gender at birth. However, individuals who wish to participate for recreational purposes only, without being included in the official ranking may register under their gender identity **Pro Divisions –**Pro division age groups will now include 60–64 and 65–69, meaning these categories will receive an official ranking and flag. But world championship spots will only be available to those age group in the Open division as that is what they would use at the World Championships. **Additional Doubles Age Groups**– Doubles age groups have been updated to align with the Singles divisions and are now structured in 5-year increments **Shoes**– Shoes must be worn at all times during the race except for the Wall Ball station, where if an athlete decides to remove them, they must be placed under the rig and carried to the finisher stage **Respiratory Devices**– Asthma inhalers or prescribed respiratory devices are permitted to be carried during the race **Medical Device**– If a medical device requires proximity to a racer’s phone is necessary during the race, prior approval must be obtained from the Race Director

Commenting on the changes,

**Mintra Tilly, Director of Sport at HYROX **said “ *We’ve been constantly evaluating the existing movement standards and penalty system throughout the season and as a result, these were the changes that we deemed necessary. Our aim is to make sure that as HYROX continues to grow as a sport, we remain consistent in the quality of racing and fair when it comes to the penalties given and guidelines for disqualification.”*

You can find the full rule books on the HYROX website here. We advise that everyone reads it before racing as the format has changed and it is a lot cleared than in previous seasons.
contents.title: 2025/26 HYROX Rulebook Updates - Rox Lyfe

contents.snippet:
A HYROX race consists of 8 functional fitness stations (or exercises), each preceded by a 1km run. In total, you perform 8 1km runs, and perform work at 8 different stations. Each HYROX station contains a different movement with a unique weight, distance, or rep requirement.

HYROX races always take place indoors in large exhibition halls. The running usually takes place on the outside of the hall, while all the exercises are placed inside of the running track.

You’ll run 1km, head in to complete your first workout station, then head back out on your next 1km run. You repeat this 8 times.

Let’s discuss the station order, race format, layout, and explain the distance and rep requirements for each HYROX station.

## HYROX Stations

The 8 HYROX stations, in order, are:

- Ski – 1000m

- Sled Push – 50m

- Sled Pull – 50m

- Burpee Broad Jumps – 80m

- Row – 1000m

- Farmer’s Carry – 200m

- Sandbag Lunges – 100m

- Wall Balls – 100 reps

For each HYROX division, the distances & reps remain the same (exception: adaptive divisions). However, different weights are used depending on which division you’re competing in. See our guides below 👇

- All HYROX weights, by division & station →

- Learn more about HYROX Doubles and the HYROX Relay

- Simplified version of all the HYROX rules →

Now let’s break down the 8 HYROX stations, sometimes referred to as HYROX exercises.

### 1. 1000m Ski

The ski is the very first HYROX station, after completing your first 1km run. All HYROX races use a Concept2 SkiErg for the ski.

All HYROX divisions complete 1000m on the ski before moving on to their second 1km run.

Doubles teams can split up the 1000m ski however they’d like. One person can do all 1000m, you can split it 500m apiece, switch every 100m, etc.

👇 We break down the ski setup, strategy, and more in our comprehensive guide below.

- Complete guide on the HYROX ski station → (coming soon)

### 2. 50m Sled Push

After completing your second 1km run, you’ll enter the sled push station. All participants must complete 50m of a sled push.

The 50m is broken up into 12.5m sections. You’ll push down 12.5m. Then push the sled another 12.5m back to its starting position. Repeat this down and back one more time for a total of 50m.

Once completing the sled push, you’ll head out (usually the opposite way you entered) for your third 1km run.

👇 We break down the sled push setup, strategy, and more in our guide below.

### 3. 50m Sled Pull

After your third run, you’ll enter the sled pull station. The setup looks similar to the sled push, with the same 12.5m sections. Only this time, you use a rope to pull the sled 12.5m, then jog down to the other side, and pull the sled back with a rope attached to the opposite side of the sled.

You’ll complete a total of 50m of sled pull before heading out for run #4.

👇 We break down the sled pull setup, strategy, and more in our guide below.

### 4. 80m Burpee Broad Jumps

The fourth HYROX station is the burpee broad jumps. When you arrive to this station, you start with your hands and feet behind the starting line. You’ll do a burpee, then jump forward. You’ll continue to do a burpee plus a jump, until you have completed all 80m.

Each race might have a slightly different burpee broad jump setup, but most venues have either:

- 80m in one continuous length

- 40m down, 40m back

- a zigzag pattern with ~20m lengths (i.e. down, back, down, back)

👇 We break down burpee broad jump setup, strategy, and more in our guide below.

- HYROX burpee broad jump guide → (coming soon)

### 5. 1000m Row

The 1000m row is the fifth HYROX station. All HYROX races use a Concept2 RowErg for the row station.

All HYROX divisions complete 1000m on the row before moving on to run #6.

You’ll enter the row station, go to the row that the judge instructs you to, adjust your damper and foot straps, row 1000m, and then exit the station from the opposite end you entered. You must remain in your seat until your screen shows 1000m.

Doubles teams can split up the 1000m row however they’d like. One person can do all 1000m, you can split it 500m apiece, switch every 100m, etc.

👇 We break down the row setup, strategy, and more in our comprehensive guide below.

- HYROX row setup, strategy & tips → (coming soon)

### 6. 200m Farmer’s Carry

The sixth station in HYROX is the farmer’s carry. Athletes will carry two kettlebells at their sides a total of 200m (see farmer’s carry weights by division). Athletes may walk, jog, or run, but must be carrying both kettlebells at their sides in order to make forward progress.

The farmer’s carry course differs from race to race, depending on the venue. You might see…

- 2 laps of 50m down and back

- 1 lap of a zigzag course, each down & back at varying lengths

👇 We break down the farmer’s carry setup, strategy, and more in our comprehensive guide below.

- HYROX farmer’s carry guide → (coming soon)

### 7. 100m Sandbag Lunges

After the farmer’s carry comes the sandbag lunges. You’ll enter the 7th HYROX station, load a sandbag on your back (see lunge weights by division), start behind the starting line, and lunge until you’ve completed 100m.

- You must lunge forward and alternate feet

- You may

**not**shuffle or step your feet between lunges

- Dropping the sandbag will incur a penalty

HYROX lunge courses also vary by venue.

- 50m down and back

- ~25m down and back, in a zigzag format

👇 We break down the sandbag lunge setup, strategy, and more in our resource below.

- HYROX sandbag lunge strategy guide → (coming soon)

### 8. 100 Wall Balls

Wall balls are the 8th and final HYROX station. Once you’ve completed your 100th wall ball, congratulations 🎉. You are now a HYROX finisher!

You’ll enter the wall ball station after your 8th 1km run. Judges are usually there to direct you to a specific lane. Make sure you pick up the correct weight ball, squat below parallel, and hit the correct target.

👇 We discuss the wall ball setup, strategy, and more in our guide below.

- HYROX wall ball station guide → (coming soon)

## HYROX Race Format & Layout

HYROX is a standardized fitness race, with the same movements, same distances, in the same order, every race. However, there are slight variations in the race format, as each race takes place in a different venue. And not all venues allow for an identical setup each time.

Here’s an example HYROX race layout from the North American Championships in Washington, DC, USA in March 2025.

**The yellow striped rectangle on the far right**is where spectators cross into the viewing area **The black with yellow striped area**is open to spectators to watch the action

The HYROX race format will always contain the following:

- The HYROX start tunnel

- A running track around the outside of the venue

- Workout stations situated inside of the running track

- Some additional space inside the running track, before you reach each workout station (aka: the Roxzone)

- Finish line

### Start Tunnel

This is one of the most unique & exciting aspects of a HYROX race, especially if it’s your first time. At every event, HYROX builds an inflatable start tunnel where all athletes gather before they start the race.

It’s a darker, semi-enclosed environment, with lights and a separate speaker system to hype you up before you start. There’s a hype person to give you a pep talk before it’s go time, and a countdown clock counts down the seconds before you take off.

⚡️ I can almost guarantee it’ll be one of the most electric starts to a race you’ve ever experienced.

Once you take off, you’ll immediately be sent onto the running track…

### Running Track

Due to venue differences, the HYROX running track is different at each event. In general, it will resemble an oval shape, and run around the outside edge of the venue.

- Some running tracks are about 300m in length, requiring 3 laps to complete 1km

- Some are closer to 250m in length, requiring 4 laps to complete 1km

- A few might be around 500m in length, requiring only 2 laps to complete 1km

Please reference your specific HYROX race map to see how many laps you need to complete.

The running track contains two lanes—a fast lane and a regular lane. Try to stay in the regular lane, unless you are passing someone. As each new wave of athletes is released, they will likely take off in the fast lane, so be aware of your surroundings.

Once you’ve completed your 1km run around the track…

### In & Out Arches

The in & out arches are an important component to understanding the HYROX race format. These are the openings in the running track where you will enter and exit the running track to go in and out of the Roxzone, where all the workout stations are found.

They are usually located on the same side of the running track, but sometimes the in arch will be closer to the start line, and sometimes the out arch is closer. It just depends on your venue.

You always enter the Roxzone through the IN arch and exit the Roxzone back onto the running track via the OUT arch. Penalties are assessed for going in or out the wrong arch.

### Roxzone

As soon as you exit the running track to head to a workout station, you enter what is called the Roxzone. You may walk, jog, or run through the Roxzone to get to the station you need to complete.

The Roxzone at each race is different, but your split times will include how much time you spent in the Roxzone throughout the race.

Most hydration stations are found within the Roxzone.

It’s important to note that while you might think a HYROX race consists of 8km of running (8 x 1km laps), HYROX has stated that the running laps combined with the distance in the Roxzone always equals 8.7km total.

You will run in the Roxzone to find the arch with the name/number of your next station.

### Workout Stations

At every HYROX, the 8 workout stations are always contained within the inside of the running track. However, they are not always in the same order, or even the order that they are to be completed. It’s your responsibility to remember which station you are on, and find the appropriate arch for that station.

You’ll enter through the station arch to complete your station work.

Upon finishing your station work, you’ll travel through the Roxzone, but this time you’ll look for the OUT arch to get back onto the running track.

### Finish Line

You’ll complete this process 8 times, and finish with the final station, wall balls. There is no run after the wall balls—you run up the ramp to the finish line, where you can look for your name & finishing time on the giant screen.

And that is the HYROX layout, in a nutshell.

### Merch, Sponsors, Spectators, Etc.

Outside of the actual race, you’ll find additional things at every HYROX event:

- Registration

- Bag drop

- Spectator grandstand

- Sponsor booths

- Merchandise area

- Relay exchange zone

- Hydration stations

- Medical station

- Recovery area

- Finish zone

- Ceremony stage

Many of these are self-explanatory, but let’s discuss the ones that affect the actual format of a HYROX race.

#### Spectator Grandstand

You might also see this referred to as the “HYROX Thunderdome,” but this is essentially a large seating area for spectators to watch the event. It is almost always situated in and around station 8, the wall balls.

Any athlete or spectator may visit this area as often as they’d like throughout the day to watch the action unfold.

#### Hydration Stations

If you need water or electrolytes during the race, there are one or two stations where you can find replenishment. The hydration stations are usually located inside of the Roxzone, but this varies by venue. Look at your specific race map to see where they are located for your race.

#### Relay Exchange Zone

The relay exchange zone is only for those competing in the HYROX relay division. This is where your relay partners will be staged as they wait for you to complete your leg. Once you’ve finished your 1km run and subsequent station, you’ll enter the relay exchange zone, locate the athlete on your team assigned to the next leg, and tag them in.

#### Finish Zone

The finish area is the final part of a HYROX course that you’ll encounter, and it’s an exciting one. All HYROX races finish up a small ramp and on a small stage, backed by a massive screen with finishing times, as well as lights and a DJ.

Once you’ve completed your 100th wall ball, head up the ramp and between the two pillars to finish your race on the HYROX finishers stage.

When you’re ready to sign up for a race, check out our guide to HYROX tickets, including some important changes for the 2025/26 season.

If you have any questions about the HYROX stations or race format, please reach out on Instagram (@fitnessexperiment.co). We’d be happy to help 😀.
contents.title: Burpee Broad Jumps – 80m

content.text:
Now I have comprehensive data from official sources. Let me compile the complete verified fact database.

---

# HYROX VERIFIED FACT DATABASE v2.0
**Last Updated: February 16, 2026 | Compiled from Official HYROX Rulebooks + Verified Sources**

---

## CRITICAL ERROR CORRECTIONS

| # | v1 Model Error | Correct Answer | Source |
|---|---|---|---|
| 1 | "Sled pull weight is same as sled push" | **WRONG.** Sled push is heavier than sled pull in every division. | Official HYROX Rulebook 2024/25 & 2025/26, §9.2 & §9.3 |
| 2 | "Run 8 is after Farmer's Carry" | **WRONG.** Run 8 is after Sandbag Lunges (Station 7). Farmer's Carry is Station 6. | Official HYROX Rulebook §8.1 / §9 station numbering |
| 3 | "This run is downhill in most venues" | **WRONG.** ALL Hyrox races are held indoors on flat surfaces. There are no hills or elevation changes. | Official HYROX Rulebook §1: "HYROX, an indoor mass participation fitness competition"; Wikipedia confirms "hosted indoors in exhibition halls or convention centers." |
| 4 | "World record 1:39 by Alexander Roncevic" for sled push | **CANNOT VERIFY as a sled push station record.** Alexander Roncevic holds the Men's Pro *overall race* world record of 53:15 (Hamburg, Oct 2025). HYROX does not officially publish individual station world records. | roxlyfe.com/hyrox-world-records (last updated Feb 2026) |

---

## 1. COMPLETE WEIGHT TABLES

### Source: Official HYROX Single Rulebook Season 2025/26 (hyrox.com) + Doubles Rulebook Season 2024/25

**KEY FACT: Sled Push weight ≠ Sled Pull weight. Push is HEAVIER than Pull in every division.**

#### Station Weights — Singles (Individual)

| Station | Distance/Reps | Open Women | Pro Women / Open Men | Pro Men |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Sled Push** | 50m (4×12.5m) | **102 kg** incl. sled | **152 kg** incl. sled | **202 kg** incl. sled |
| **Sled Pull** | 50m (4×12.5m) | **78 kg** incl. sled | **103 kg** incl. sled | **153 kg** incl. sled |
| **Burpee Broad Jumps** | 80m | Bodyweight | Bodyweight | Bodyweight |
| **Farmer's Carry** | 200m | 2 × 16 kg (white) | 2 × 24 kg (grey) | 2 × 32 kg (black) |
| **Sandbag Lunges** | 100m | 10 kg (white) | 20 kg (grey) | 30 kg (black) |
| **Wall Balls** | 100 reps | 4 kg ball | 6 kg ball | 9 kg ball |
| **Wall Ball Target Height** | — | 2.70 m | Women: 2.70 m / Men: 3.00 m | 3.00 m |
| **SkiErg** | 1,000 m | Same for all | Same for all | Same for all |
| **Rowing** | 1,000 m | Same for all | Same for all | Same for all |
| **Running** | 8 × 1,000 m | Same for all | Same for all | Same for all |

**Damper Settings** (2025/26 Season): Preset to **Resistance 6 for ALL divisions** on both SkiErg and Rower. Athletes may adjust as desired. *(Source: 2025/26 Rulebook §9.1 — note: this changed from 2024/25 where it was 5/6/7 by division)*

#### Station Weights — Doubles

| Station | Distance/Reps | Doubles Women | Doubles Men / Doubles Mixed / Doubles Women Pro | Doubles Men Pro |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Sled Push** | 50m total (YGIG) | **102 kg** incl. sled | **152 kg** incl. sled | **202 kg** incl. sled |
| **Sled Pull** | 50m total (YGIG) | **78 kg** incl. sled | **103 kg** incl. sled | **153 kg** incl. sled |
| **Burpee Broad Jumps** | 80m total (YGIG) | Bodyweight | Bodyweight | Bodyweight |
| **Farmer's Carry** | 200m total (YGIG) | 2 × 16 kg (white) | 2 × 24 kg (grey) | 2 × 32 kg (black) |
| **Sandbag Lunges** | 100m total (YGIG) | 10 kg (white) | 20 kg (grey) | 30 kg (black) |
| **Wall Balls** | 100 reps total (YGIG) | 4 kg ball | 6 kg ball | 9 kg ball |
| **SkiErg** | 1,000 m total (YGIG) | Same for all | Same for all | Same for all |
| **Rowing** | 1,000 m total (YGIG) | Same for all | Same for all | Same for all |

*Doubles: Both partners run all 8 × 1km together. Station work is split using YGIG (You Go, I Go) — only one partner works at a time. Both partners must enter and exit each station together.*

*Mixed Doubles wall ball target: Women use 2.70m target, Men use 3.00m target.*

#### Relay Division
Relay teams (4 people) use **Open division weights**. Each person completes 2 runs + 2 stations. *(Source: hellohyrox.com verified against official relay rulebook description)*

---

### Sled Push vs. Sled Pull: Weight Difference Breakdown

| Division | Sled Push (incl. sled) | Sled Pull (incl. sled) | Difference (Push heavier by) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Open Women | 102 kg | 78 kg | **24 kg** |
| Pro Women / Open Men | 152 kg | 103 kg | **49 kg** |
| Pro Men | 202 kg | 153 kg | **49 kg** |

**Why the difference?** The sled pull is lighter because the pulling motion (hand-over-hand rope pulling while standing stationary in a box) is biomechanically more demanding — it relies primarily on upper body (arms, back, grip) rather than the powerful leg drive available in a sled push. Additionally, the athlete cannot use bodyweight as leverage the way they can when pushing. The lighter weight on the pull compensates for this biomechanical disadvantage.

**Note on sled weight:** The listed weights are **total weight including the sled itself.** The sled body typically weighs approximately 30–52 kg depending on the model. The "added plates" are stacked on top. For example, Men Pro sled push = ~52 kg sled + ~150 kg in plates = 202 kg total. *(Source: pace-club.com notes sled is "usually ~30-40 kg"; exact sled weight varies by model)*

---

## 2. STATION ORDER & RUN MAPPING

### The Exact Complete Race Sequence
*(Source: Official HYROX Rulebook 2025/26 §8.1 + §9.1-9.8; fitnessexperiment.co; confirmed identical across all sources)*

| Segment | Activity | Details |
|---|---|---|
| **START** | Start Tunnel | Inflatable tunnel with countdown, lights, hype |
| **Run 1** | 1 km run | First run; may be slightly shorter, balanced later |
| **Station 1** | **SkiErg** | 1,000 m |
| **Run 2** | 1 km run | |
| **Station 2** | **Sled Push** | 50 m (4 × 12.5 m) |
| **Run 3** | 1 km run | |
| **Station 3** | **Sled Pull** | 50 m (4 × 12.5 m) |
| **Run 4** | 1 km run | |
| **Station 4** | **Burpee Broad Jumps** | 80 m |
| **Run 5** | 1 km run | |
| **Station 5** | **Rowing** | 1,000 m |
| **Run 6** | 1 km run | |
| **Station 6** | **Farmer's Carry** | 200 m |
| **Run 7** | 1 km run | |
| **Station 7** | **Sandbag Lunges** | 100 m |
| **Run 8** | 1 km run | |
| **Station 8** | **Wall Balls** | 100 reps |
| **FINISH** | Finisher Stage | Up ramp to finish line — **NO run after Wall Balls** |

### Station-to-Run Mapping with Fatigue Impact

| Run | Preceded By | Followed By | Fatigue Impact |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Run 1** | Start tunnel | SkiErg (St. 1) | Fresh legs; use to warm up and settle into pace. Don't blast out too fast. |
| **Run 2** | SkiErg (St. 1) | Sled Push (St. 2) | Upper body slightly fatigued from ski pulling motion; legs relatively fresh. Breathing may be elevated. |
| **Run 3** | Sled Push (St. 2) | Sled Pull (St. 3) | Quads and glutes fatigued from heavy sled push; this is one of the hardest runs. Legs feel heavy, especially the first 200m. |
| **Run 4** | Sled Pull (St. 3) | Burpee Broad Jumps (St. 4) | Forearms, biceps, and back fatigued from pulling; legs had some rest during the pull. Running feels easier than post-push. |
| **Run 5** | Burpee Broad Jumps (St. 4) | Rowing (St. 5) | Full-body fatigue; shoulders from burpees, quads from repeated jumping. Heart rate typically spikes. Mental low point for many. |
| **Run 6** | Rowing (St. 5) | Farmer's Carry (St. 6) | Legs tired from rowing drive phase; back/arms pre-fatigued. Use this run to recover for the grip-intensive carry. |
| **Run 7** | Farmer's Carry (St. 6) | Sandbag Lunges (St. 7) | Forearms/grip fatigued but legs relatively fresh (carry is mostly walking). However, overall accumulated fatigue is high. |
| **Run 8** | Sandbag Lunges (St. 7) | Wall Balls (St. 8) | **The hardest run.** Quads and glutes are destroyed from 100m of lunges. Many athletes struggle to run; walking portions common. This is the most critical run to train for. |

### Has the Station Order Ever Changed?
The station order has remained the same since HYROX's inception. It is **identical for the 2024/25 and 2025/26 seasons.** The official HYROX website and all sources confirm: "The same eight workout stations, always in the same order." *(Source: fitnessexperiment.co; rezerv.co)*

**One historical change:** Women's Wall Balls were increased from **75 reps to 100 reps** in the Open and Women's Doubles divisions starting from September 2024 (Cape Town event, 21 Sept 2024). Pro Women have always done 100 reps. *(Source: roxlyfe.com world records page, Note 2)*

## 3. VENUE DETAILS

### Indoor/Outdoor Confirmation
**CONFIRMED: Nearly all HYROX races are held INDOORS.**
- Official Rulebook §1 (both 2024/25 and 2025/26): *"HYROX, an indoor mass participation fitness competition"*
- Typical venues: **convention centers, exhibition halls, arena/expo complexes** (e.g., ExCeL London, Javits Center NYC, Messe Hamburg)
- **One known exception:** Wikipedia notes: *"Occasional events have been hosted outdoors, including Miami in 2023."* This is extremely rare and not the norm.
- *(Sources: HYROX Official Rulebook §1; Wikipedia "Hyrox" article; fitnessexperiment.co)*

### Running Surface
- **Sled stations:** HYROX uses the official **HYROX × Centr Perform Turf** — a custom-engineered 16mm polyethylene/polypropylene artificial turf specifically designed for sled push/pull. Debuted at 2025 World Championships in Chicago, now rolling out globally. *(Source: centr.com shop listing; roxlyfe.com; findyouredge.app)*
- **Running track:** The running surface varies by venue — typically the **concrete/hard floor of the exhibition hall**, sometimes with thin carpet or rubber overlay. It is NOT on outdoor pavement, grass, or standard athletic track rubber. The floor is hard and flat.
- **Burpee Broad Jumps / Lunges:** Generally performed on turf or the venue floor.
- *(Source: Various race reports; HYROX turf product specs; venue walkthrough videos)*

### Is the Course FLAT?
**YES — confirmed FLAT. No hills, no elevation changes, no inclines.** All races are inside exhibition halls with level concrete floors. The only minor "elevation" is the small ramp up to the finisher stage at the very end. *(Source: All official rulebooks; venue walkthroughs; every course map shows flat layout)*

### Turns on the Running Course
**Yes, there are turns.** The running course is typically an oval/loop around the perimeter of the exhibition hall. Depending on the venue:
- Rectangular venues may have **4 turns** (roughly 90-degree corners per lap)
- Turns can be relatively tight in some venues
- Multiple laps per 1km means multiple turns per run segment
- At HYROX London ExCeL 2025, the course was a single full 1km lap — the first time this was done *(reducing total turns)*
- *(Source: fitnessexperiment.co; YouTube venue walkthroughs)*

### Course Layout
- **Running course:** A **loop** around the outside perimeter of the venue (not out-and-back). The running track encircles the workout station area.
- **Laps per 1km run:** Varies by venue:
  - ~250m track → **4 laps** per 1km
  - ~300-333m track → **3 laps** per 1km
  - ~500m track → **2 laps** per 1km
  - ~1000m track → **1 lap** (rare; HYROX London ExCeL 2025 was the first)
  - Check venue-specific athlete guide for exact lap count
- **Station areas:** All 8 workout stations are located **inside the running loop**, accessed through the Roxzone via IN/OUT arches
- **Roxzone:** Transition corridor between the running track and the stations; adds approximately 700m to total distance over 8 transitions (total course distance ≈ 8.7km including Roxzone, per HYROX's own statement)
- **Station physical placement:** Stations are not necessarily laid out in numerical order within the venue — athletes must find the correct arch for their current station number
- *(Source: fitnessexperiment.co; Official Rulebook §8.3; 2025/26 Rulebook §8.3)*

### Spectator Areas
- **Spectator grandstand ("Thunderdome"):** Usually located near Station 8 (Wall Balls) and the finish line
- Spectators can see the wall balls area and finish clearly
- Spectators **cannot** see the entire race — the running track and most stations are spread across a large venue
- Some venues have additional viewing areas along the running track or near certain stations
- Spectators are **not permitted** in the warm-up area
- *(Source: fitnessexperiment.co; Official 2025/26 Rulebook §12.3)*

### Venue Temperature
**UNVERIFIED from official sources.** Exhibition halls are typically climate-controlled but can get warm due to:
- Thousands of athletes generating heat
- Indoor venues with limited airflow
- Estimated typical conditions: 18-25°C (65-77°F), variable humidity
- Athletes should prepare for warmer-than-expected indoor conditions

## 5. OFFICIAL RULES & PENALTIES

### General Rules
*(Source: Official HYROX Single Rulebook Season 2025/26)*

**Allowed Equipment:**
- ✅ Knee sleeves
- ✅ Gloves (not grips — change for 2025/26)
- ✅ Weightlifting belt
- ✅ Wristbands
- ✅ Hydration packs (must carry from start)
- ✅ Asthma inhalers or prescribed respiratory devices *(new for 2025/26)*
- ✅ Weight vests and uniforms (if not interfering with other racers' safety)
- ✅ Closed-toe shoes (required at all times EXCEPT at Wall Balls where shoes may be removed)

**Prohibited Items:**
- ❌ **Headphones** — strictly forbidden
- ❌ Cell phones *(exception: medical device requiring phone proximity needs Race Director pre-approval)*
- ❌ VR headsets
- ❌ GoPro or any body cameras
- ❌ Helmets
- ❌ Breathing apparatus / compressed air cylinders
- ❌ Any item not explicitly listed as permitted

**Timing Chip:** Must be attached to an **ankle** at all times. Failure = Did Not Start (DNS). *(Source: 2025/26 Rulebook §8.1, §12.1)*

**Start time** must be clearly visible written on the racer's arm. Starting in the wrong wave = **DQ**. *(New rule for 2025/26)*

### Station-Specific Rules

#### Sled Push (§9.2)
- Athlete assigned to a specific lane by judges — **must use assigned lane**
- Both sled and athlete must start completely behind the white line
- Sled must fully pass the 12.5m mark before changing direction
- Station complete when sled passes the line after 4 × 12.5m
- **First infringement:** warning; **Second:** 15-second penalty; **Each subsequent:** 15-second penalty
- **Missing lane:** 3-minute penalty per missing lane

#### Sled Pull (§9.3)
- Athlete must remain **standing** — sitting/kneeling NOT permitted
- Athlete must stay within the **Racers Box** at each end; **must NOT step on the solid white line at the front or back** of the box while holding the rope *(clarified for 2025/26)*
- Rope must stay within own lane
- 4 × 12.5m to complete
- After pulling sled to one end, athlete runs to opposite end and pulls back
- **Same penalty structure** as sled push

#### Wall Balls (§9.8)
- Must start standing tall, holding ball with both hands (cannot pick up and immediately throw)
- Squat must go **below parallel** (hips below knees)
- Ball must hit the **designated target area** (strike zone)
- Women target: **2.70 m** | Men target: **3.00 m**
- A squat depth box may be used at judge's discretion
- Invalid rep = "no rep" — **no warning, just a no-rep**
- Missing reps: **15 seconds per missing rep** *(2025/26 penalty)*
- Digital targets may auto-track reps (new technology being deployed)
- Athletes may remove shoes at this station only; shoes must be placed under the rig and carried to the finisher stage

#### Burpee Broad Jumps (§9.4)
- Chest (nipple line) must clearly touch the ground on every burpee
- Hands placed no more than 30cm forward of toes for subsequent burpees *(clarified in 2025/26)*
- Both feet must be parallel for takeoff AND landing — no staggered feet, no steps, no shuffles
- When stepping/jumping out of burpee, feet cannot pass fingertips
- Athletes **may use their knees** to step up from the bottom position *(new clarification for 2025/26)*
- Station complete when athlete jumps over the finish line (if a foot lands ON the line, another rep required)
- **Penalty:** 15-second per infringement after first warning *(changed from 5m distance penalty)*

#### Farmer's Carry (§9.6)
- **Yes, athletes CAN put weights down to rest** — but kettlebells must not move forward when placed on ground
- Must carry BOTH kettlebells at all times while moving; arms extended at sides
- Station complete when kettlebells cross finish line and are returned to correct box with handles upright
- **Wrong weight = must redo entire station; failure = DQ** *(2025/26 rule)*
- Kettlebell return penalty: 30 seconds if not returned correctly (can be avoided if corrected before exiting Roxzone)
- May involve **multiple laps** depending on venue *(2025/26 clarification)*; each missing lap = 3-minute penalty

#### Sandbag Lunges (§9.7)
- Trailing knee must clearly touch the ground each rep
- Must stand fully tall between reps (hips/knees fully extended)
- Lunges must alternate legs
- No steps or shuffles between reps
- Sandbag must remain on BOTH shoulders at ALL times (including turn zones)
- **First removal of sandbag from shoulders = 15-second penalty (NO warning)** *(2025/26: stricter than before)*
- **Second removal = DISQUALIFICATION**
- Wrong weight = must redo entire station; failure = DQ

### Penalty Summary Table (2025/26 Season)

| Infraction | Penalty |
|---|---|
| Missing run lap | 3-7 min depending on venue setup; DQ for 1-lap setup |
| Missing entire run or station | **DQ** |
| Wrong station order (1 station) | 3-minute penalty (can correct before Wall Balls) |
| Wrong station order (2+ stations) | **DQ** |
| Wrong IN/OUT arch | 2 minutes per infringement |
| Sled: missing lane | 3 minutes per missing lane |
| Sled/BBJ/Lunge: movement infringement | Warning → then 15 sec per infringement |
| Wall ball no-rep | 15 sec per missing rep (no warning) |
| Farmer's carry: missing lap | 3 minutes per lap |
| Farmer's carry: wrong return | 30 seconds |
| Wrong weight (carry/lunges) | Must redo; failure = **DQ** |
| Sandbag dropped (1st) | 15 seconds (no warning) |
| Sandbag dropped (2nd) | **DQ** |
| Starting in wrong wave | **DQ** |
| Outside assistance (food/drink from non-aid-station) | 3 minutes per infringement |
| Spitting/clearing nose on floor | 2 minutes or DQ |
| Littering / rapid cooling with water | 2 minutes per infringement |
| Using chalk at Wall Balls | 2 minutes |
| Using wrong equipment/lane | 2 minutes per infringement |

### 2025/26 Season Rule Changes
*(Source: roxlyfe.com/2025-26-rulebooks; Official 2025/26 Rulebook compared to 2024/25)*

**Summary of Key Changes:**

| Area | Change |
|---|---|
| **Erg dampers** | Now preset to **6 for ALL divisions** (previously varied 5/6/7). Can still be adjusted by athlete. |
| **Penalty system overhaul** | Distance-based penalties (5m, 10m) on sleds, BBJ, and lunges **replaced** with **time-based penalties (15 seconds)** after one warning |
| **Sled Pull box line** | Clarified: athletes must NOT step on the solid white line at the front of the Racers Box |
| **Burpee Broad Jumps** | Clarified: athletes **may use knees** to step up from bottom position; hands max 30cm from toes |
| **Wrong wave start** | Now = **DQ** (was not previously codified this strictly) |
| **Farmer's Carry** | May involve multiple laps; each missing lap = 3 min penalty; wrong weight = redo or DQ |
| **Sandbag removal** | 1st = 15s penalty (no warning); 2nd = DQ *(was previously 5m then DQ)* |
| **Wall Ball reps** | Digital targets being introduced; missing reps = 15 sec each |
| **Shoes** | Must be worn at all times except at Wall Balls |
| **Pro age groups** | Now extend to 70-74 (previously ended at 55-59) |
| **Doubles age groups** | Restructured to 5-year increments (aligned with Singles) |
| **Respiratory devices** | Asthma inhalers now explicitly permitted |
| **Rankings** | Based on biological gender at birth; recreational participation under gender identity allowed but unranked |
| **Terminology** | "Participants" → "Racers"; "Workout" → "Station"; "World Championships" → "WORLDS" |
| **Outside assistance** | 3-minute penalty per infringement (changed from penalty/DQ at discretion) |
| **Water at aid stations** | May NOT be used for active cooling (pouring over head/body) = 2 min penalty |

**Weights: NO weight changes between 2024/25 and 2025/26 seasons.** All station weights remain identical.

**Station format: NO changes.** Same 8 stations, same order, same distances/reps. The only recent format change was Women's Open Wall Balls from 75→100 reps (September 2024).
